content: are these the next revolution in dungeon crafting let's find out hey guys welcome
back to another episode of black magic craft not that long ago I did a video
about the textured rolling pins from green stuff Worldcom these were pins
that were designed to be used to sculpt miniature bases and give some texture to
polymer clay but through some experimenting I realized that they
worked really well on my material of choice XPS foam and after that video
came out these textured rolling pins kind of blew up in the dungeon crafting
community and I think green stuff WorldCom noticed I say this because a
few months after that video came out they developed a tool that was
specifically geared towards dungeon tile building previously all of their
products and tools were sort of geared towards war gamers but now all of a
sudden they've released the dungeon plunger cutter I can't help but think
that the development of this dungeon tile cutter product was in some way
influenced by our corner of the community all of a sudden using their
tools for dungeon tiles which I'm guessing is why they were keen to send
me these to test out now what are these dungeon plunger cutters they are these
nifty little almost like cookie cutter type things that are designed to be used
in polymer clay things like fimo or sculpey roll some out in a thin layer
stab it like a cookie cutter and use the plunger to press in a texture and then
bake that clay and you have yourself a little dungeon tile that you can glue to
a board and use for your terrain purposes the set comes with six plungers
there's three different stamps one is sort of a square brickwork one
is a cobblestone and one is a flat just blanked square here's where it gets
interesting each one of those patterns has two sizes you'll get one that's a
one-inch square and one that is an inch and a quarter square and I think this
means they've been paying attention to not only my videos but also while oxd
some of you I'm sure will realize that a inch and a quarter square tile is
perfect to use for why locks style dungeon tiles and I think it's no
coincidence that these come in both sizes and if it is a coincidence it's a
happy one today I test it out these plungers using some super sculpey I
rolled some out made a couple of each pattern put them in the oven it doesn't
take that long it's like 15 minutes in the oven once they came out I was left
with some pretty nice looking thin square tiles I cleaned up the edges a
little bit with an exacto knife and then I just glued them to a piece of
chipboard after a quick paint job I was left with a pretty great-looking little
dungeon tile the plungers were very easy to use and they had really nice-looking
results but I'd like to give my first impression pros and cons of the tool
itself and its application the main thing I like about this tool and what it
creates is that it allows you to make incredibly thin dungeon tiles very very
thin but it also has a really nice amount of weight to it and it's very
solid and very durable it's also got a really detailed texture I think that a
tile like this would be ideal for people who have issues with storage or who
travel you could fit a lot more of these tiles into a box or on a shelf than my
usual XPS foam ones another nice thing is that because this type of tile
creation involves no styrofoam no XPS no foam-core you can spray-paint it which
will help speed up your build process a bit the material the sculpey or polymer
clay fimo whatever you want to use also won't need something like the Mod Podge
to make it more durable this is gonna be a boat as strong as you could possibly
want for a dungeon tile just with the raw material itself this is also a
pretty good option for people who cannot get their hands on XPS foam which I know
can be a challenge for people in certain places I'm not sure but I think that
polymer clay is a pretty universal product
I think fimo and sculpey kind of dominates the crafting market so
wherever you are if you have some sort of hobby or craft store you can probably
get your hands on a material that will work with these punches now for the
things I don't like one the plungers are useless on XPS foam
I checked on XPS foam if you could quickly punch in a little textured
pattern because if so it would be great to make a quick gridded square but they
don't work for that they are not sharp enough or hard enough or whatever they
just they don't really work on XPS foam and I wouldn't bother getting them if
that's the intended use you have for them don't bother the other downside is
that as far as I'm concerned fimo and sculpey are possibly a little too
expensive for some crafters definitely in terms of number of tiles that you can
make XPS foam for example is going to be cheaper cardboard is going to be cheaper
fimo and sculpey is a little bit more expensive it's still not that bad
because for one pound of fimo you can make a lot of tiles so if you buy one of
those packs with a coupon it is still fairly cost effective but definitely not
as frugal as XPS foam I had the idea to try out the plungers with some really
cheap air dry clay from the dollar store unfortunately I found that the clay the
kind of natural earthy air dry clay did not work well with the plungers they it
got stuck in it it there it was just impossible to
cut the pattern tiles and pull them out and keep them in one piece the clay was
just too sticky even when I tried working with water and different things
and it was kind of a mess and a bit of a failure that being said I have a feeling
that a higher quality air dry clay something like gas modelling clay may
actually work and be a little bit more affordable than FEMA or sculpey and
would skip the step of baking in the oven but I haven't had a chance to test
that out yet so I don't want to say it would work for sure overall I don't
think that this tool and this style tile is going to be a replacement for my type
of foam dungeon tiles because I think what you are left with is two very
different types of tiles what I think these would be exceptionally good for is
if you have decided to build a set of Y lock style tiles because in his build he
essentially makes a square of cardboard and uses chipboard cut up in layers to
glue down as the individual squares and using these plungers and some polymer
clay would allow you to do his build but in a more high-end fancier style and
because they were smart enough to manufacture these with an inch and a
quarter plunger size included it is made perfectly for why locks
excellent form factor system I've been thinking about making a set of his tiles
for a while and how they could integrate with my style of crafting and never
really got around to it I think now with these plungers and the
clay that time going to go about building my set of Y lock style tiles I
really like these I think that they are a simple and nifty little tool and they
create a really nice result but I don't think they are as epic game changing in
style as something like the textured rolling pins because those rolling pins
were exceptionally good because they made building terrain fast you could
take one of those rolling pins roll it out on some foam and instantly have a
textured wall or floor pattern and it allowed people like me to do speed
builds these aren't gonna do that these are not a tool that's gonna speed up
your dungeon building these are a tool that will allow you to make a certain
type of tile really well namely a thin hard durable tile with no warpage this
is not a tool to speed up efficiency this is a tool to give you a very unique
and specific product result these are not a tool that are going to be
universally useful to all dungeon crafters but for those of you out there
who would make use of something like this it's going to be a phenomenal
addition to your arsenal the price of these is really reasonable as far as I'm
concerned for a set of six of these plungers they are like twelve euro
currently on the website they are listed as 10% off and greenstuff world has been
nice enough to set Blackmagic craft up with a unique promo code that you can
use the info for that code is in the description of this video so if you act
now you can combine my code with their plunger sale and get these for 15% off
which works out to be about 10 euros or about 12 for 1250 USD which is pretty
darn reasonable if you want to pick up a set of these for yourself head on over
to green stuff WorldCom link to the product is in the description make use
of that black magic craft promo code if you want to pick up any other tools or
supplies to achieve this build like some fimo some chipboard whatever head on
over to black magic craft CA there you will find my essential equipment store
where I link to all of the tools that I use regularly and recommend that you can
buy on Amazon and in the process help the channel oh by giving me a small
Commission on those sales these video would not be made if it were not for the
support of people on patreon the generosity of supporters on patreon are
the number one reason these videos come out every single Friday and I thank
every single one of you patreon supporters for that help and generosity
if you want to help out and join the cause head on over to my patreon there
you can join the black magic craft Fellowship and join a group of great
fellow crafters get some direct help from me on your build and in the process
help fund these videos that I do for the community if you've tried these plungers
for yourself already I would love to hear how you found them drop a comment
below and let me know your thoughts on the product and until next week guys
Cheers and happy crafting
